msIdentifier.collection: Civil War & Reconstruction Governors of Mississippi, Main Collection

note.p: John Marshall Stone served as governor of Mississippi two separate times, from 1876 to 1882 and from 1890 to 1896.

Born in Milan, Tennessee, on March 29, 1876, Stone grew up mostly in poverty but worked for his education and eventually became a school teacher. He moved to Mississippi in the mid-1850s and found work as a railroad station agent at Iuka, Mississippi. When the Civil War broke out in 1861, Stone joined the Confederate army. He was placed in command of Company K of the 2nd Mississippi Infantry Regiment. Proving capable in battle during campaigns in Virginia, he was promoted in 1862 to colonel of the regiment and received high praise from his superiors during the rest of the war. Stone led his regiment until near the end of the war, when he was captured in North Carolina and sent to Ohio as a prisoner.

Upon his release after the Civil War, Stone returned to Mississippi and resumed his work with the Mississippi and Ohio Railroad at Iuka. He married Mary G. Coman in 1872 and had two children, both of whom died before adulthood. Stone and his wife also adopted and raised three of his nephews.

He entered politics in 1869, winning election to the Mississippi state senate as a Democrat. In 1873 and 1874, Democrats in Mississippi gained majority power following campaigns of voter intimidation and violence against African Americans and Republicans. Stone worked his way to president pro tempore of the Senate during this period. In 1876, the Democrat majority in the state legislature carried out an impeachment campaign against top Republican officials, including Governor Adelbert Ames and Lieutenant Governor Alexander K. Davis. When Davis was impeached and Ames was forced to resign to avoid a costly lawsuit against politically-driven impeachment charges, Stone became next in line for governor. He was sworn into office in March 1876.

Stone served as acting-governor for a year and a half and then won the gubernatorial election in 1877, running as the sole candidate. He lost reelection in 1881 to Robert Lowry, but retained his interest in the governor’s office and ran again—and won—in 1889. Mississippi adopted a new constitution in 1890, which in part extended Stone’s gubernatorial term until 1896 to aid the transition of new policies. The new constitution prohibited successive gubernatorial terms. Thus, Stone could not run for immediate reelection. Upon leaving office, he received an appointment as president of the Mississippi Agricultural and Mechanical College (now Mississippi State University) in Starkville. He died in 1900 and is buried at Oak Grove Cemetery in Iuka, Mississippi.
(Wikipedia; Dan Sansing, “John Marshall Stone: Thirty-first and Thirty-third Governor of Mississippi: 1876-1882; 1890–1896,” Mississippi History Now)
John Marshall Stone belonged to the following social groups:
Located in Pickens County, Alabama, Carrollton was founded in 1830 and serves as the county seat. (Encyclopedia of Alabama; Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)

gloss.p: Engaging in "illegal activities." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"To become free or get free from, or to avoid something," especially to escape from custody. (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The crime of taking something that does not belong to you, but not in a way that involves force or the threat of force." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The processing of individuals who have committed criminal acts." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The act of using legal authority to catch and take someone to a place where the person may be accused of a crime." (CD)
"An amount of money set for a person accused of a crime to be released from a law enforcement facility until trial." (Cambridge Dictionary)

catDesc.term: Criminal Procedures--Charges and Specifications (Civil and Criminal)

gloss.p: "To make a formal statement saying that someone is accused of a crime." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"Having officially been found guilty of a crime in a law court." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The act of formally accusing someone of a serious crime." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A person who is in charge of a trial in a court and decides how a person who is guilty of a crime should be punished, or who makes decisions on legal matters." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A public officer who judges local and less important legal cases, and performs marriage ceremonies." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"Individuals responsible for enforcing laws in designated areas." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"In the U.S., an official whose job is to be in charge of performing the orders of the law courts and making certain that the laws are obeyed within a particular county." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A person who works in an office, dealing with records or performing general office duties." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A place where trials and other legal cases happen, or the people present in such a place." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A place where criminals are kept as a punishment for their crimes or while waiting for trials." (Cambridge Dictionary)

Operating at the state level, the Alabama Executive Department was established by Article IV of the Alabama Constitution (1819) on July 5, 1819 and is headed by the Office of the Governor. All agencies and offices within the Department are subordinate to the Governor. The Alabama Executive Department consists of a governor, lieutenant governor, attorney-general, state auditor, secretary of state, state treasurer, commissioner of agriculture and industries, and a sheriff for each county. (Avalon Project-Alabama: Constitution of 1819; Alabama Department of Archives & History)

catDesc.term: Alabama--Office of the Secretary of State

gloss.p: Operating at the state level, the Office of the Secretary of State of Alabama was established by Article IV of the Alabama Constitution (1819) on July 5, 1819. It is an office within the Executive Department, headed by the Secretary of State. The Secretary is primarily responsible for authenticating gubernatorial actions, maintaining records and databases of original laws. Prior to 1868 the Secretary was appointed by vote of the State Legislature but after 1868 became publicly elected. (Encyclopedia of Alabama; Avalon Project-Alabama: Constitution of 1819; Wikipedia)

catDesc.term: Minnesota--Office of the Secretary of State

gloss.p: Operating at the state level, the Minnesota Secretary of State is elected by the state for a four-year term and is responsible for overseeing state election laws and government records. (Wikipedia)

Operating at the state level, the Executive Department of the State of Mississippi consists of the governor, lieutenant governor, secretary of state, state treasurer, state comptroller, commissioner of agriculture, commissioner of insurance, the Mississippi Public Service Commission, the Mississippi Transportation Commission, and attorney general. Each official is elected for a four-year term and is appointed duties pertaining to state regulations. (Wikipedia)

The term "fugitive from justice" is defined broadly and covers a multiplicity of experiences under U.S. law, but refers most often to "a person who is fleeing from custody, whether it be from jail, a government arrest, government or non-government questioning, vigilante violence, or outraged private individuals" (Wikipedia). Slightly different than the above definition, a fugitive from justice may also be defined as "a person formally charged with a crime or a convicted criminal whose punishment has not yet been determined or fully served who is currently beyond the custody or control" of the party, be it local, national, or international, interested in their arrest (Wikipedia). In the nineteenth-century United States, fugitive status varied widely based on race. Many white people considered "fugitives from justice" were most often the latter definition, being those charged with or convicted of crimes who then fled across other state lines to try and evade punishment or trial. However, throughout American history up to Emancipation, fugitive status was given to escaped enslaved African Americans under the Fugitive Slave Laws of 1793 and later 1850. These laws also required anyone in the nation to apprehend self-emancipated enslaved people and return them to their owners. The term "fugitives from justice" therefore became another legal mechanism by which enslavers sought to control the movements and freedoms of the enslaved, while contributing heavily to the increasing sectionalism that would lead to the American Civil War (Britannica). To learn more about enslaved people who emancipations themselves and were labeled fugitives, see the "Emancipation and self-emancipation" subject tag under Events.

div.p:
STATE OFALABAMA,
PICKENS COUNTY
County COURT.
Personally appeared before me M. F. Cook Judge of Circuit Court
[gap]

for said county, Sam Kennedy who being sworn says on oath that the offence of Escape from me was committed by Pat Jones alias Ned Salmonds who was committed to carry to Jail, being convicted of Petit Larceny and escaped from affiant while he was carrying him to jail, has been committed, and that he has good reason to believe, that Pat Jones Alias Ned Salmonds is guilty of Escape from lawful officer Custody of affiant and was found guilty of Larceny before Jno W. Cox J. P. of Pickins County Ala is guilty thereof.
Sam ^his X mark^ Kennedy
Sworn to and subscribed before me, this 17 day of December 1881.

M. F. Cook
Judge County Court

THE STATE OF ALABAMA,
PICKENS COUNTY.
Pickens^County^ COURT:

p.hi: TO ANY LAWFUL OFFICER OF THE STATE OF ALABAMA—Greeting:

div.p: Complaint on oath having been made before me that the offence of Escape from lawful Custody of Sam Kennedy, the said Pat Jones alias Ned Salmonds having been committed to him to carry to Jail in default of bail has been committed, and accusing Pat Jones alias Ned Salmonds hereof, You are therefore commanded forthwith to arrest the said Pat Jones alias Ned Salmonds and bring him before me at Carrollton at the next regular term.

M. F. Cook
Judge of County Court

[gap]
[gap]

STATE OF ALABAMA
PICKENS COUNTY.
[gap] COURT.
We, [gap]
[gap]
agree to pay to the State of Alabama the sum of [gap] hundred dollars, unless the said
[gap]
appear at the next term of the [gap] Court of said county, and from term to term thereafter, until discharged by law, to answer the charge of [gap]
[gap]
preferred against [gap] by [gap]
Witness our hands and seals, this [gap] day of [gap] 188
Approved this [gap] day of [gap] 188
[gap]

[gap] [SEAL.]
[gap] [SEAL.]
[gap] [SEAL.]

The State of Alabama
Pickens County

I, W. Y Robertson. Ex officer Clerk of the County Court of said County certify that the within is a true Copy of the original affidavit and warrant of arrest against one Pat Jones Alias Ned Salmonds, as appears on file in the Clerk's office of said Court.
Witness my hand this 17t day of December A D 1881.

W. Y Robertson
Clerk of County Court.
No. [gap]

STATE OF ALABAMA,
PICKENS COUNTY.
[gap] COURT.

COMPLAINT, BOND
and
WARRANT OF ARREST.
vs.
[gap]
Issued [gap] day of [gap] 188[gap]
[gap]
Received [gap] day of [gap] 188[gap]
[gap]
WEST ALABAMIAN Job Print, Carrollton, Ala.

p.b: In the Name and by the Authority of the

div.p: [image: eagle and shield with ribbon inscribed: HERE WE REST]
STATE OF ALABAMA
To his Excellency the Governor of the State of Mississippi

WHEREAS It appears by the annexed Copy of Indictment duly authenticated in accordance with the laws of this State, that—Pat Jones, alias Ned Salmonds—stand charged with the crime of——Escape—committed in the County of Pickens in this State and it has been represented to me that he has fled from the justice of this State and has taken refuge in the State of Mississippi—

Now Therefore presented to the provisions of the CONSTITUTION and LAWS of the UNITED STATES in such case made and provided I DO HEREBY REQUEST that the said—Pat Jones, alias Ned Salmonds—be apprehended and delivered to Sam Kennedy—who is hereby authorized to receive and convey him to the State of Alabama [unclear: obstructed by ribbon] according to law.
[seal] * ALABAMA * GREAT SEAL [/seal]

In Witness Whereof, I have hereunto set my hand and caused the GREAT SEAL of the STATE to be affixed at Montgomery this 22nd day of Decr. in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and Eighty one

R. M. Cobb
GOVERNOR OF ALABAMA.
BY THE GOVERNOR:
Requistion From Alabama For. Pat. Jones. alias Ned. Salmonds.
[gap]
Recd at Executive Office and Warrant Issued and Mailed, December 24th 1887.

J. M. Stone—Governor of the State of Mississippi.
To the Sheriff of—County,

p.hi: Or to the Sheriff of any other County--GREETING:

div.p: WHEREAS, His Excellency, the Governor of the State of Alabama—has made known to me that Pat. Jones, alias Ned. Salmonds—stands charged with having committed the crime of——Escape—(as set forth in the annexed copy of an Affidavit—which is hereby certified to authentic,)
And, Whereas, It appears that said Pat. Jones, alias. Ned Salmonds—has fled from justice and is to be found in the State of Mississippi, where he has taken refuge;

And, Whereas, The Governor aforesaid, has demanded of me the arrest and delivery of said Pat Jones, alias Ned. Salmonds—to—Sam Kennedy—whom he has appointed agent to receive and convey said Pat. Jones, alias. Ned. Salmonds to the jurisdictional limits within which he stands charged,

Now, Therefore, I, J. M. Stone—Governor of the State of Mississippi, do, by virtue of the power vested in me by the Constitution and Laws of this State, direct and require you to arrest the said Pat. Jones, alias Ned. Salmonds—and deliver him to the cus-tody of the said Sam. Kennedy—the agent appointed by the Governor of Alabama—to the end that he may be conveyed to the jurisdictional limits where he stands charged.

p.hi: Witness my hand and signature, and the Great Seal of the Stateof Mississippi hereunto affixed, this

div.p: J. M. Stone.
[seal] THE GREAT SEAL OF THE STATE OF MISSISSIPPI [/seal]
By the Governor:

Henry C. Myers
SECRETARY OF STATE.

OFFICE OF
Secretary of State,
STATE OF MISSISSIPPI,
[gap] County.

From The Governor
Address [gap]
Dated Dec. 24 1881
Received ,, ,, 1881
Commissioned [gap] 188[gap]
Answered [gap] 188[gap]

Requistion rep from Alabama for Pat. Jones al-ias Ned. Sal-mons an Es-cape—
Affidavit
[gap]

HENRY C. MYERS,
Secretary of State.
